citations.narrative:
There were electrical cords on the countertop where the young Eurasian Eagle Owl in the room adjacent to the gift shop
was perching. These cords were within reach of the animal and used for charging the communication radios, and to
supply power to the guidance lights, a coffee maker and a microwave.
Electrical cords that the birds can access may cause injury or death if bitten or if the bird becomes entangled.
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Electrical cords must not be accessible to birds.
Corrected at time of inspection.

There were no records of disposition for one bovine, one domestic rabbit, three fennec foxes, one capybara, two barbary
sheep, one otter, one elk, one kangaroo, two prehensile-tailed porcupines, one green- winged macaw, one military
macaw, three ostriches, one Moluccan cockatoo and one black swan. These animals were listed on the last animal
inventory but were not present at this inspection. The facility had acquired a squirrel monkey since the last inspection but
did not have acquisition records. Additionally, records were provided on this inspection for two tiger cubs acquired on
25SEP2024. These animals and records were not made available on the inspection conducted on 30SEP2024 and
therefore APHIS officials were not provided the opportunity to inspect the required paperwork or animals.
The absence of acquisition and disposition records prevents the ability to trace and track animals in the event of an
animal disease outbreak, and to ensure all parties that require a USDA, APHIS, AC license hold a current and valid
license.
Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and exhibitor shall make,
keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning animals other
than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The
records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her
control, to the extent that any identification or counting of offspring can be carried out without unduly disturbing nesting or
rearing activities.
To be corrected from this day forward, January 31 , 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Kristin Ray, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There were electrical cords on the countertop where the young Eurasian Eagle Owl in the room adjacent to the gift shop 
was perching. These cords were within reach of the animal and used for charging the communication radios, and to 
supply power to the guidance lights, a coffee maker and a microwave.  
Electrical cords that the birds can access may cause injury or death if bitten or if the bird becomes entangled. 
Housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird 
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering 
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Electrical cords must not be accessible to birds.  
 
Corrected at time of inspection. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
There were no records of disposition for one bovine, one domestic rabbit, three fennec foxes, one capybara, two barbary 
sheep, one otter, one elk, one kangaroo, two prehensile-tailed porcupines, one green- winged macaw, one military 
macaw, three ostriches, one Moluccan cockatoo and one black swan. These animals were listed on the last animal 
inventory but were not present at this inspection. The facility had acquired a squirrel monkey since the last inspection but 
did not have acquisition records. Additionally, records were provided on this inspection for two tiger cubs acquired on 
25SEP2024. These animals and records were not made available on the inspection conducted on 30SEP2024 and 
therefore APHIS officials were not provided the opportunity to inspect the required paperwork or animals.  
The absence of acquisition and disposition records prevents the ability to trace and track animals in the event of an 
animal disease outbreak, and to ensure all parties that require a USDA, APHIS, AC license hold a current and valid 
license. 
Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and exhibitor shall make, 
keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning animals other 
than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The 
records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her 
control, to the extent that any identification or counting of offspring can be carried out without unduly disturbing nesting or

rearing activities. 
 
To be corrected from this day forward, January 31 , 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Kristin Ray, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
